instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> tries to turn on 0A - 0.4A - 0A after previous black screen issue and shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Hi Guys, 

Have this board that has a black internal screen but used to work on the external screen. A graphic load software won't start on the external screen. 
Thought it could be a <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> cold joint issue and resoldered it, in the process resoldered <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> as well. Afterwards, the board won't even turn on and would stay at 0.28A with and without a battery. 

Found short on <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>. Not sure if the heat somehow triggered it, went and replaced it. Now it tries to turn on and switches off with a battery, keeps repeating it -  0A - 0.44A - 0A

Measured that 
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - jumps 0 - 3.3V and repeats, together with P3V3/<SIGNAL>P5V_S5_EN</SIGNAL> signals.

Went through the board to hunt for shorts but couldn't locate any. 
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is SMC output line, how I can check if losing voltage before?

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> tries to turn on 0A - 0.4A - 0A after previous black screen issue and shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
SMC will disable the signal, if detects a problem on the board.

External monitor is driven by discrete GPU only.
How could <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> cause missing internal video???
You've caused more damage on the board doing something not related with your problem.
Resoldering <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is a must do on this board; but not generating another problem!

Touching <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> with initial problem, was bad idea.
Some bad solder caused <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> fried.

Remove <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR> and test the board again.
Also try starting in SMC bypass mode.

You may need to change <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> now.
Check all its resistors and traces to <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> tries to turn on 0A - 0.4A - 0A after previous black screen issue and shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Had this before with a 2013 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> model as described by TCRS - [MEDIA=youtube]FF7wsStjyj4:435[/MEDIA]. Resoldering pads resolved the problem in that case. Thought this could be the same as it wasn't showing internal video, but external seemed to be working.

Agree. I should not have touched <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. The low resistance on its pins deceived me.

Removed <RESISTOR>R7940</RESISTOR> and tried SMC Bypass (if this is the one) by shorting <CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR>, doesn't even attempt to turn on.

Resoldered <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> a couple of times now and seem to make good contact. Traced the PHASE1/2 and UGATE2, traces seems to be fine
<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is listed as <CHIP>ISL95831</CHIP> on the schematic but MAX15199 on the board. Seems I can grab <CHIP>ISL95831</CHIP> from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, is that same as the MAX?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> tries to turn on 0A - 0.4A - 0A after previous black screen issue and shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Compare schematics, to choose equivalent IC.
3332 uses same chip as 3115 and 3330 (MAX15119).
2915 has different layout (MAX17511).
<CHIP>ISL95831</CHIP> is not compatible with them.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> tries to turn on 0A - 0.4A - 0A after previous black screen issue and shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
I have replaced the <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. No fan spin stays at 0.28A and can see the replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> gets hot.
But have very low resistance on <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PHASE1</SIGNAL>/2 - 1Ohm. Is it expected?

Also seems like it blow the <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> again, shall i replace it one more time? I have lifted the coils around the CPU and lower side is the CPU side.

[ATTACH type="full" alt="1662361282768.png"]60761[/ATTACH]

With removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> it turns on and spins the fans
[ATTACH type="full"]60762[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> tries to turn on 0A - 0.4A - 0A after previous black screen issue and shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
CPU may have very low resistance to ground as normal; just compare with other similar board.

However, burning <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> probably fried the CPU.
